thread.title: Karina Vetrano slay suspect previously threatened to attack women
thread.title_full: Karina Vetrano slay suspect previously threatened to attack women

author: ROCCO PARASCANDOLA, CHELSIA ROSE MARCIUS, STEPHEN REX BROWN
title: Karina Vetrano slay suspect previously threatened to attack women
text:
Karina Vetrano slay suspect previously threatened to attack women New York Daily News 2 hrs ago ROCCO PARASCANDOLA, CHELSIA ROSE MARCIUS, STEPHEN REX BROWN < PREVIOUS SLIDE SLIDE 1 of 3 NEXT SLIDE > Administrators of Chanel Lewis’s high school once called police saying he had threatened to hurt women with a knife, sources said. - James Keivom/New York Daily News © Provided by New York Daily News The man accused of killing Karina Vetrano once ranted at his Queens high school that he hated women and wanted to hurt them with a knife, police sources told the Daily News.
The suspect in the notorious slaying , Chanel Lewis, had no criminal record prior to being charged Sunday with strangling Vetrano, 30, as she jogged in an overgrown area of Howard Beach.
But sources said police have discovered red flags hinting at his deranged motive.
Administrators of Martin De Porres High School, where Lewis was a student, once called police and reported that he had said he hated women and threatened to use a knife against them, a source said.
Police did not arrest Lewis, 20, but did document the incident as involving an emotionally disturbed person.
It was unclear when the incident occurred at the private school dedicated to children with emotional and behavioral issues.
He repeated his hatred of the opposite sex in a more recent encounter with police, sources said. But the threat again did not warrant an arrest, police determined.
"There was nothing actionable," the source said. "There was no victim. There was no complainant.”
Lewis’s sister, Theresa Forbes, said he was not a woman hater.
"He loves girls. He was very protective," she said, referring to the women in his life.
She added that her brother wasn’t “ready” for a girlfriend and never hung around Howard Beach.
"We're not killers, we're church people. They set him up,' Forbes, 36, said. "I think the cops framed him because he's a black person."
She said she was sorry for the Vetrano family's loss, but that the wrong person was in custody. Lewis's DNA was found on Vetrano's body.
"The DNA lies sometimes. They wanted to get confirmation so they framed him for murder. My family, we are God-fearing people. The Bible tells us 'Do not kill.' We do not kill," Forbes said.
Lewis was "pretty forthcoming" and gave a detailed account of the killing, a police source said. Detectives Lewis happened upon Vetrano and launched the vicious attack. He did not admit to sexually assaulting the victim, sources said.
He is charged with second-degree murder.
But Forbes wasn't buying it.
"I think they coerced him into a confession. They tricked him," she said.
She pointed out that Lewis is a rail-thin 6 feet tall and 140 pounds — and bears little resemblance to a police sketch released of a suspect in the Aug. 2 attack.
"Look at the sketch, that's not him," Forbes said. "He's a skinny guy, she's a strong person. He could never kill a person like that."
Lewis’s mother said he was innocent at her home in East New York, Brooklyn.
"He's not guilty. Tell them to go look for the real killer," she said.
A next door neighbor, who would not give his name, said Lewis “was slow” and “stayed to himself.”
Lewis’s father previously denied his son could be a killer , and noted that he had received good grades at school.
NYPD Commissioner James O'Neill was expected to address the case during an update Monday on citywide crime statistics.
